U. S. RED CROSS HIRES OCEAN LINER WOUNDED Hamburg-American Steamer Hamburg, as American Hos pital Ship, Sails Saturday.
TAKES 200 DOCTORS. Warring Governments Will Recognize Neutrality of Ves sel Manned by Americans.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (Asso ciated Press). The American Red Cross announced to-day that it had chartered the steamer Hamburg of the Hamburg American line, which will be renamed Red Cross and sail on Saturday for Europe. ... Miss Mabel T. Boardman, chairman of the National Relief Board of the American Red Cross, will go to New York to-night to take personal charge of the final preparations for the de parture of the ship. The Hamburg ... will be painted white, with a red "hospital band" around the upper part of her hull ...

ONLY SOLDIERS WILL RECEIVE RED CROSS AID Helping of Europe's Hungry People Given Up for Field Service. SECRETARY GARRISON. Annual Report Calls for 25,000 More Regulars, Additional Officers to Train Recruits, and Immediate Legislation Providing Trained Reserves...
To better shoulder the titanic task of ministering to the tens of thousands of wounded and dying soldiers in the battling armies of Europe, the American National Red Cross, at its tenth annual meeting at the Shoreham yesterday, dropped the staggering burden of feeding, clothing and otherwise aiding the suffering and starving noncombatants of Europe.
The Red Cross was forced to take action unprecedented in its long annals of humanitarianism. This was done upon the motion of Vice President Robert W. de Forest, of New York...
President Woodrow Wilson, president of the Red Cross, presided but a few minutes, but while he held the gavel he made an address which clearly expressed his deep interest in the Red Cross...
Miss Mabel T. Boardman, chairman of the National Relief Board, in speaking on "The Red Cross and the European War," expressed "deep grief" that the Red Cross should be forced to relinquish its efforts for the alleviation of suffering among the noncombatants...
Miss Jane A. Delano, vice chairman of the nursing service... explained that during the last month hundreds of nurses have volunteered aid and hundreds of men have offered to serve as orderlies and stretcher bearers. "The nurses and surgeons now in Europe," said Miss Delano, "represent eleven states and twenty-four cities." ...

ARE YOU KNITTING YOUR ... The Moving Picture People Find Time between Scenes to Help Red Cross in Its Big Winter Drive.
Florence Nightingale Not Founder, as Commonly Supposed; Organization Due to Efforts of Clara Barton
Ask who founded the Red Cross and nine persons out of ten will reply confidently "Florence Nightingale." ... The inspiration of a noble American woman completed the work of the Red Cross society ... This was Clara Barton, born the year after Miss Nightingale ... Today the necessity for universal skill [in knitting] is greater than in those other days ... millions of boys in khaki and blue are clamoring for the warm, worsted garments which the Red Cross is collecting ...

Keeping Pershing's Army in Good Spirits Henry P. Davison, Chairman of the Red Cross War Council, Explains the Way Our Soldiers Are Informed Truthfully of Home Conditions
If a cross section photograph could be taken to-day of the activities of the American Red Cross, both at home and abroad, the resultant picture would be a great comfort to every woman who has a husband or brother, father or son, enlisted in America’s fighting forces. For it would show a scope of endeavor far greater than the original function of the Red Cross, which was merely to care for the wounded. The wounded still get attention, all that the best doctors and nurses can give them; but that is only one phase of the work that the American Red Cross now symbolizes. The rest of the picture is new. ... “In this new picture, which has been enlarged to meet the demands of modern warfare, the flag of the American Red Cross flies over every camp and cantonment where American men are being trained for battle, symbolizing a protection to their morale as well as their creature comforts. ... ‘Moreover, every parcel [to POWs] is personally receipted for by the prisoner, and the postcard receipt sent back to the Red Cross ... The Red Cross has already begun to send food and clothing to him and that this service will be maintained as long as he remains a prisoner of war.’ ... ‘This is the message which the American Red Cross has carried to Europe and which it will continue to deliver there so long as there are hungry Allies to be fed, homeless ones to be housed and broken lives to be rebuilt.’

"A great net of mercy drawn through an ocean of unspeakable pain" How Was the Last War Fund Spent?
It is a fair question—and it is fairly answered in the detailed and itemized reports that have been published in the newspapers of every town and city of the land. You never saw it? Then ask at the nearest Red Cross Chapter, or write, for the Red Cross wants you to know where your money went.
They say that Red Cross supplies have a way of coming through on time. Italy surely has found us not wanting in prompt ness when her great trial came. And Roumania—they said no allied nation could get through to help her dire need. But the Red Cross found a way.
It’s not always a cheap way—“Needs must” costs money. But did you give that money to be saved—or to save lives? ... And of one thing you may be sure. Not one penny of that Hundred Million has gone for anything but War Relief.
Your Red Cross needs another hundred million to lighten just a little of the awful load of misery “over there.” Your share is all that you can give—and then a little more. Will you hold up your end?

THE BIG DRIVE FOR RED CROSS COMMENCES MONDAY Committees Appointed and Allotments Made In Various Wards. COVINGTON PARADE SATURDAY EVENING St. Tammany Parish Is Expected To Again Go Over The Top.
Parish Chairman Poitevent has appointed chairmen in the different wards to take charge of the Second Red Cross Drive, which starts Monday, May 20, and these chairmen have appointed their local committeemen. The allotments have been made for the different wards, and the total parish allotment of $15,000 has been as equitably distributed as possible...
Covington—E. G. Davis, E. J. Domergue, S. C. Bull, H. A. Mackie, ... John L. Haller, ward chairman, Third Ward, ... Each ward will provide for its own demonstrations and parades. The Covington parade will take place at 5 o'clock to-day and will be participated in by the Red Cross, the schools and St. Paul's College and St. Scholastica's Academy...
Capt. Herbert Smith, who spent nine months in the trenches at the front ... spoke for the Red Cross at Slidell and Abita Springs, and Wednesday at Covington. He related experiences of war conditions and the vital aid the Red Cross provides to soldiers in the trenches...

"NEW Red Cross Call" "Roll of Member"
Every Patriotic Citizen Urged to Help in Solution of Problems of Peace by Joining; America's Greatest Institution.
WASHINGTON, D. C. Henry P. Davison, Chairman of the War Council of the Red Cross, has issued to the 3,884 chapters and 22,000,000 members of the American Red Cross the following statement outlining the future policy of the American Red Cross:
"The Roll Call of the nation is thus to be called at Christmas time, that through enrollment in their Red Cross the American people may send a message to our soldiers still overseas and to the peoples of the world that we are not merely content with seeing our privates united with our allies in victory, but that our abiding purpose is that the love, the sympathy and the intelligence of all America shall be re-dedicated to the permanent service of mankind." —H. P. DAVISON

"A Great Net of Mercy drawn through an Ocean of Unspeakable Pain" —American Red Cross
The Call From No Man's Land
The Spending of Your Hundred Million Dollars Busiest Budget in All the World Is a Red Cross War Fund —Every Dollar Spent Alleviates Misery.
Last summer the public subscribed a hundred million dollars to the Red Cross. ... It’s amazing that it [the Red Cross] has done so much with so little money.
... The American Red Cross’ enormous job is to do whatever it can to alleviate [suffering]—not after the war, not after governments have deliberated and resolved; but right now, on the spot. ...
[Article describes in detail how millions of dollars in Red Cross funds were spent to assist refugees, to build hospitals, to provide food, shelter, medical services and canteen services for soldiers in France, Italy, and elsewhere, alleviating misery on an unprecedented scale...]
Every dollar it spends means misery alleviated. Its work is building abroad for the United States the best good will in this world. Whatever else the war may produce, we shall be proud of our Red Cross.
—From the Cottonwood chronicle (Idaho), May 10, 1918.

HALLOWE'EN* SOPHY LA??GHAM'S DIARY.
MALDON HALL, October 27, 1846.— We have been a week here to-day, and I have never once opened my diary. This year is fast waxing to its close, and I feel I must write retrospectively, recording the events omitted, as best I can, from memory.
Our parting from mamma was a sad one; we had never left her be? fore. Still, Miss Langham's invita? tion came so unexpectedly, and with the mention of All Hallow E'en drawing near, that we decided to accept. Perhaps in this ancient Hall we shall witness old customs or legends of the season. The old tree-lined drive and the chill autumn twilight gave me a strange sense of awe when we arrived here...
I can hardly believe Hallowe'en is so close at hand. There is a hush throughout these grand halls, as if the house itself remembered ages past of our family. We shall see what the vigil of All Hallows brings.

THE ELECTION--Tr E REIULT As FAR As HEARD FROM-ALL HALLOW RYE--AL SAINTS DAY.
ITurning from the thread-bare subject of politics, which have been discussed with animation for several months past, I will say a few words about
ALL HALLOW EVE. The last of October, the eve of All Saints Day, has been for ages a time of festivities, peculiar costumes and ceremonies, in the old countries, but of these there are few traces in our country. It is a season when fairies and wood-land elves come out in force, play pranks on passers by, dance merrily on the bill sides, and perform fa vors for those who have the good fortune to meet with them and fall into their good graces ...

A NIGHT OF MYSTERY. Some Curious Facts Concerning All Hallow Even.
The Night When Maidens Try to Find Out Who Will Wed Them— A Curious Cir- cumstance— Tricks Played.
[Written for The Morning Call]
All boys and girls know that October 31st is "All Hallow Even," though most of them corrupt its name to "Holly Eve." They know that it is a night of mirth and mys- tery specially devoted to mischief, fun, in- cantations, divination charms and spells, but very few of them or their elders under- stand its real significance or can tell whence it derives its name.
It is many centuries since the Roman Church, finding it impossible, from the great and constantly increasing multitude of the saints, to set apart a separate day for each one, decreed that November 1st should thenceforward be kept as a day in honor of all the saints, and that it should be known as All Hallow Mas, or All Saints' day, and that the night of October 31st, immediately preceding it, should thereafter be kept as a vigil and known as All Hallow eve, these occasions being still observed in the Cath- olic, Episcopal and Lutheran churches...

TIS FAIRIES NIGHT. ALL Halloween, when to your sight may be, I ween, Some curious facts concerning All Hallow Even.
From its first origination Hallow eve has been invested with a peculiarly mystic character. It is an almost universal super stition that supernatural influences then have unusual power—that devils, witches and fairies roam free; that all spirits are loosed to roam through space, and that the spiritual element in humanity can be detached to read its own future or reveal the fortunes of others.

On Tuesday, October 31, is Halloween, Halloween. The very mention of Halloween calls up visions of ghosts and witches and all kinds of uncanny things. It is the one night in the year when even the uninitiated, if they are brave enough, may converse with spooks and hobgoblins, and may also, if they try hard enough, send the immaterial part of their being prancing through space on all kinds of errands. But the grand object of all the mystic rites peculiar to Halloween is to find out who one’s future spouse will be—that being a very important question with those who have never had one.
Another way that does not require so much courage is to write the alphabet on twenty-six little slips of paper, one letter on each slip, and then turn them face down in a basin of water. This done, go to bed backward and in silence. Next morning some of the letters in the basin will be found face up and the name thus revealed will give the desired information.

Halloween was the eve of Hallowmas, and on that night ghosts, goblins, witches and fairies were believed to be turned loose upon the Earth. It also was the favorite time for testing fortune, for the veil that hid the future hung so waveringly that one, by proper signs and devices, might get a peep behind it.
In many tests of fortune the apple plays a part, big with prophecy of things to come. Eat one before a mirror in a darkened room on Halloween and your future spouse will look over your shoulder; throw the peel over your left shoulder and it will form the initial of the one you are to marry.

OUR SPECIAL FEATURE PAGE
No holiday on the calendar depends more for its charm upon tradition and the customs handed down from generation to generation than does that fateful night of mirth and mystery—Hallowe'en. ... Hallowe'en not only retains its time-honored significance and long-established ritual but finds its chief attraction in these reminders of bygone periods.
The festival of the night of October 31 has a number of different designations, though none are so commonly used as Hallowe'en. ... From time out of mind this has been heralded as a night when witches, devils and other mischief-making beings go abroad on their baneful midnight errands. By a strange coincidence, however, this same night is supposed to be devoted by the fairies to a grand anniversary celebration.

Now approaches the witch's hour, when, hand in hand with jack-o'-lantern, she is prepared to scamper across the curtain for an interlude of frolic. The black cat is with us again, and the bat, and the owl. The cauldron bubbles, the chestnuts burn upon the hearth, the Hallowe'en cake gives up its ghostly prophecy of wealth, matrimony or a life of single blessedness...
Hallowe'en 'nativities are always very popular with girls, and they are possible for every one, for the celebration of the night has one great advantage in the fact that its mystic rites and ceremonies can be just as well and happily performed by three or four persons as by a large number. Naturally the sort of Hallowe'en entertainment which is arranged for a small gathering is not satisfactory for a large one...

FAIRIES' HALLOWEEN PARTY
The Halloween fairies were giving a party. There was the pumpkin fairy, in shimmering shining yellow; the apple fairy in russet and green; the nut fairies in golden browns, and many others into the bargain. They were giving their party in the hollow of a great big oak tree. Friendly fireflies had offered to furnish the illumination, and so many of them came that there wasn’t the least bit of danger that their lights would all go out at the same time...
The Origin of Halloween
The only mysterious festival left to prosaic Americans is Halloween. Its origin is plainly Pagan, although the romantic element has come to us from England, Ireland and Scotland. Around the 1st of November the Druids were supposed to hold their worship of the sun god, thanking him for the harvest. Huge sacrificial fires were lighted in his honor, which influence can still be seen in the “bonfire night” in Ireland. This is the night when witches, elves, and evil spirits walk abroad, souring the cream, tying cats’ tails together, and performing pranks usually attributed to small boys.

Hostelries Keeping Program Secret Until Opening
By THE NIGHT CLUB EDITOR If Washington case society doesn’t celebrate Halloween this year it won’t be the hotels’ fault. Every hostelry in town is making fevered preparations for the festival and all of ’em are trying to keep it a secret—until the opening. Sande Williams and his orchestra now playing in the Shar-Zad Room at the Carlton Hotel are holding rehearsals behind locked doors. Those weird sounds can mean only one thing. The witches and goblins are tuning up.
The Shoreham will make a special occasion of this autumn festival partly because it is Halloween and partly because it marks the eighth anniversary of the hostelry’s opening. Nadine Petrey, Washington’s own Halloween queen, will visit the Blue Room. Nadine, a pretty lass of 17, will be accompanied by her ladies-in-waiting, her jesters, and—of course—her king.

Boys and girls were afforded an opportunity to learn the initials of the person most closely connected with their futures in one Halloween frolic. A dish of water darkened with sepia, and another of clear, were produced, as well as sticks of sealing wax—one half white, the other black. To discover the first (Christian) name, a youth or maiden lighted the white wax, holding it over the dish of dark water until a drop fell, then dipped it out on a spoon. Sometimes the initial was clearly indicated; in others, there was a faint suggestion, or no shape at all, interpreted as either a doubt of romance or a fate too distant to be revealed.
In another pretty charm, a small tub of water was used. The names of unmarried men were written on squares of paper, twisted to resist the water, then placed afloat. At the same time, a candle end—glued to a chip—was lit and set adrift. If the flame first ignited one of the papers, that indicated the youth would be the lassie’s next suitor, for he "had first felt the fire of love.”

Halloween is just around the corner, which means extra special gayety in the after-dark spots. Every spot that caters to whoopee-makers is making an extra effort for a gala evening. Entertainment ranges from the usual noisemakers to the importation of headline acts from New York—so collect your energy, shekels, and fine duds and go out and have yourself a time.
Tomorrow night is the first anniversary of the opening of the Maryland Winter Gardens, and this event, along with Halloween, ought to make, and probably will, an evening full of entertainment. Brian McDonald, master of ceremonies, is back after an eight months absence, and it looks like plenty of war-whooping out on the old Marlboro Pike.

WITCH-LIKE ACTIONS Would Have Meant Sure Death in the Old Days
Even in our own country the hallucinations that certain persons were endowed with the power of conversing with evil spirits ran riot in the little colony of Salem in 1692. At that time persons were put to death or imprisoned not only for being witches, but for asserting their unbelief in witchcraft. Today the people of the little Massachusetts town still point out “Witches’ Hill,” where several innocent women were executed. The madness of the colony spared neither the weak-minded Indian maiden Tituba, who was seen practicing ceremonies of her own heathen religion, nor such exemplary women as Sarah Cloyce and Rebecca Nurse.
Cats Are Always Connected With Halloween Celebrations
Cats are always singled out as closely connected with witches and with Halloween. Long before any real knowledge of the animal’s habits existed, cats were believed to be endowed with magic powers, and it was thought “bad luck” to kill one, since the creature’s spirit might seek vengeance. Hence the black cat, companion of witches and a symbol of mystic powers, remains a staple element in modern Halloween festivities, to give the night’s frolic that eerie effect of the unknown.
